On the Practicality of Differential Privacy in Federated Learning by Tuning Iteration Times

Yao Fu, Yipeng Zhou, Di Wu, Shui Yu, Yonggang Wen, and Chao Li Yao Fu and Di Wu are with the Department of Computer Science, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, 510006, China, and Guangdong Key Laboratory of Big Data Analysis and Processing, Guangzhou, 510006, China (E-mail: fuyao7@mail2.sysu.edu.cn; wudi27@mail.sysu.edu.cn). Yipeng Zhou is with the Department of Computing, FSE, Macquarie University, Australia, 2122 (E-mail: yipeng.zhou@mq.edu.au). Shui Yu is with the School of Computer Science, University of Technology Sydney, Australia (E-mail: Shui.Yu@uts.edu.au). Yonggang Wen is with the School of Computer Science and Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore (E-mail: ygwen@ntu.edu.sg). Chao Li is with Tencent Technology (Shenzhen) Co. Ltd, China.(E-mail: ethancli@tencent.com).
Abstract

In spite that Federated Learning (FL) is well known for its privacy protection when training machine learning models among distributed clients collaboratively, recent studies have pointed out that the naive FL is susceptible to gradient leakage attacks. In the meanwhile, Differential Privacy (DP) emerges as a promising countermeasure to defend against gradient leakage attacks. However, the adoption of DP by clients in FL may significantly jeopardize the model accuracy. It is still an open problem to understand the practicality of DP from a theoretic perspective. In this paper, we make the first attempt to understand the practicality of DP in FL through tuning the number of conducted iterations. Based on the FedAvg algorithm, we formally derive the convergence rate with DP noises in FL. Then, we theoretically derive: 1) the conditions for the DP based FedAvg to converge as the number of global iterations (GI) approaches infinity; 2) the method to set the number of local iterations (LI) to minimize the negative influence of DP noises. By further substituting the Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms into the derived convergence rate respectively, we show that: 3) The DP based FedAvg with the Laplace mechanism cannot converge, but the divergence rate can be effectively prohibited by setting the number of LIs with our method; 4) The learning error of the DP based FedAvg with the Gaussian mechanism can converge to a constant number finally if we use a fixed number of LIs per GI. To verify our theoretical findings, we conduct extensive experiments using two real-world datasets. The results not only validate our analysis results, but also provide useful guidelines on how to optimize model accuracy when incorporating DP into FL.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Differential Privacy, Convergence Rate, Model Accuracy.

I Introduction

In the past decade, machine learning models have demonstrated unprecedented data processing capability in numerous applications. To well train machine learning models, it is unavoidable to massively collect data samples from users, which gives rise to the concern on user privacy leakage [1, 2]. This concern has significantly hindered the wide application of machine learning techniques. In light of this, Federated Learning (FL) [3] has been proposed to allow decentralized clients to collaboratively train machine learning models by merely exchanging intermediate computations (i.e., gradients) with the parameter server (PS). Raw data samples are locally kept on clients. However, it has been pointed out that the leaked gradient information can still be exploited by malicious entities to crack user privacy [4, 5, 6, 7, 8].111Users are used interchangeably with clients in this paper. To further enhance the protection of user privacy, Differential Privacy (DP) has been employed to add additional noises to client gradients before they are uploaded to the PS [9, 10, 11].

Unfortunately, the adoption of DP may lower the model accuracy significantly, which has become a major obstacle for the application of DP in FL [9, 10, 11]. Taking the popular FedAvg algorithm [3] as an example, the naive adoption of DP in FedAvg may cause 222-101010 times training loss than the original model [10]. For many real-world applications, such high performance deterioration can significantly reduce the effectiveness of advanced machine learning models, and is somewhat unacceptable at all. As FedAvg represents a large family of gradient descent (GD) based algorithms widely used in FL, it is questionable how practical DP will be when being applied to FL.

Typically, clients and the PS in FL works together with the following manner: clients conduct a number of local iterations (LI) before their gradients plus DP noises are uploaded to the PS for aggregation. By receiving the computations from multiple selected clients, the PS conducts a round of aggregation and distributes new results to clients for the next round of global iteration (GI) [12]. Apparently, it is only necessary to add the DP noises to clients’ gradients after the last round of LIs before they are disclosed to the PS. The noises distort the disclosed gradients against attacks, which meanwhile impair the convergence of FL [10, 11, 13].222Note that clients may have different privacy budgets and are independent in noise generation [14, 15]

In this work, we investigate how to improve the practicality of DP in FL through tuning the number of conducted local or global iterations. Intuitively, we can improve the model accuracy if the number of LIs is tuned properly since there is no need to add noises after each LI except the last LI. Firstly, we derive the convergence rate of the FedAvg algorithm distorted by the DP noises. Secondly, we derive the conditions for the DP based FedAvg to converge, and formally derive the formula to set the number of LIs according to the DP mechanism to minimize the negative influence of DP noises. At last, we conduct case study by using the Laplace mechanism and the Gaussian mechanism, through which we theoretically unveil that: 1) The learning error of the DP based FedAvg with the Gaussian mechanism can finally converge to a constant number if we use a fixed number of LIs per GI; 2) The DP based FedAvg with the Laplace mechanism will diverge with the number of GIs, but the divergence rate can be lowered substantially by setting the number of LIs according to our method.

Overall, our contributions in this paper can be summarized as below:

  • •

    To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to theoretically study the practicality of DP in FL through tuning the numbers of LIs and GIs, which paves the way towards a better understanding of the complicated relation between the random noises introduced by DP and the final FL model accuracy.

  • •

    We formally derive the convergence rate of FedAvg with DP noises and the convergence conditions. By substituting the Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms into the convergence rate, we theoretically investigate how to optimally tune the number of LIs and GIs so as to minimize the influence of DP noises.

  • •

    Extensive experiments with real-world datasets are conducted to validate the correctness of our theoretic results, and demonstrate the practical merit of our work, which provides us a way to optimize the FL model accuracy even if DP is adopted.

The rest content is organized as follows. The related state-of-the-art works are discussed in Sec. II. The preliminary knowledge is introduced in Sec. III. The DP-FedAvg algorithm is elaborated in Sec. IV. The derivation and optimization of the converge rate of DP-FedAvg are presented in Sec. V. The experiment results are presented and explained in Sec. VI before we finally conclude our paper in Sec. VII.

II Related Work

II-A Federated Learning

The FL framework was originally proposed in the works [3, 16, 17], which applied FL on mobile devices to predict the next word of mobile users’ text input. Both FedAvg and FedSGD algorithms used for neural network based models were empirically studied with extensive experiments in [3]. Later on, the convergence rate of FedAvg/FedSGD was analyzed in [18] with non-IID data sample distributions.

Since the inception of FL, it has attracted tremendous attentions. Kairouz et al. [12] and Li et al. [19] conducted a holistic overview of FL with in-depth technical discussions on possible weaknesses of FL. It has been proved that FL can improve the protection of user privacy to some extent [12]. However, the leakage of the gradient information can still result in the leakage of user privacy, which can be exploited by malicious users to design various attack strategies [4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

II-B Differential Privacy

Other than FL, DP is another widely adopted approach to preserve user privacy [20]. The principle of DP is to add noises to individual users’ private information before it is disclosed. Consequently, malicious attackers cannot exactly crack users’ private information even if the information is leaked. Thanks to its ability for preserving privacy, it has been applied in personalized recommendation systems [21], location based services [22], meta learning [23] and so on. However, the shortcoming of DP is that the service quality will be lowered because service providers cannot obtain precise user information as well [9, 10, 24].

II-C Applying DP in FL

DP can be applied to machine learning such as FL to enhance the privacy protection level. In FL, there exist two schemes to add DP noises: the global DP scheme and the local DP scheme. The former one adds noises to the aggregated gradient information on the server side before the gradient information is distributed to clients [13, 25]. Whereas the latter one adds noises to the gradient information on users before it is uploaded to the server [9, 26, 27, 28].

There are many existing works [29, 13, 25] that targeted to design mechanisms to add global DP noises in machine learning systems such as FL. For example, the work [13] particularly focused on using DP to mask whether a client participates in the training (i.e., client-level DP).

Prior works on the incorporation of LDP are elaborated as follows. Wu et al. [10] theoretically analyzed the convergence performance when local DP is used in a distributed learning system. Only the gradient descent algorithm is considered in this work, and its analysis proved that the GD algorithm can converge if the sample population approaches infinity, which however is impossible in practice. In addition, the scenario considered in this paper is not a typical FL setting, and the influence of the non-IID sample distribution is ignored. Wei et al. [11] considered both global DP and local DP in an FL system. Their theoretical analysis validated that the number of global iterations and the number of engaged clients in each global iteration should be neither too large nor too small to minimize the final loss function. However, only the FedSGD algorithm with IID sample distribution was mentioned in this work, which was not consistent with an FL scenario. The analysis of the FedAvg algorithm and the influence of the number of local iterations were absent in the above work.

Other than the above LDP mechanism that can guarantee the privacy budget over all rounds of global iteration, there exist a number of other works that designed and analyzed a loose LDP mechanism that can only guarantee the privacy budget for a single round of global iteration [9, 28, 30]. For example, Seif et al. [28] relaxed the local ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP in wireless FL settings, which gave fixed noises in each iteration and used advanced composition rule to track the total privacy leakage over T𝑇T iterations. However, the privacy leakage will increase to infinity with T𝑇T, though they can obtained a converged upper bound finally.

In summary, prior works have demonstrated that it is promising to incorporate DP into FL. However, how to minimize the negative influence of the noises incurred by DP has been overlooked by existing works. Especially, how to set up the number of LIs and how it affects the final model accuracy have not been explored yet, and this gap will be filled by our work.

Before we introduce our algorithm, we list the symbols and notations used in this paper, as shown in Table I. Some ofthem will be defined later in the following sections.

III Preliminaries

III-A FedAvg

In FL, there is a group of clients 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} with cardinality N𝑁N that aim to collaboratively train a model 𝔐​(θ)𝔐𝜃\mathfrak{M}(\theta), where θ∈ℝp𝜃superscriptℝ𝑝\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{p} represents the parameters of the model. Each client l𝑙l has a private data set 𝒟lsubscript𝒟𝑙\mathcal{D}_{l} with cardinality nlsubscript𝑛𝑙n_{l}. A trusted parameter server is responsible for sending model parameters to clients and aggregating updates reported back from clients in each round of global iteration. To train the model 𝔐​(θ)𝔐𝜃\mathfrak{M}(\theta), which can be represented by the loss function f​(θ)𝑓𝜃f(\theta), a common approach is to design gradient descent (GD) based algorithms (e.g., FedAvg, FedSGD [3]) to iteratively reduce the loss function.

In FedAvg, each client updates the model on the local dataset 𝒟lsubscript𝒟𝑙\mathcal{D}_{l} for E𝐸E epochs, following the rule:

θ←θ−η​∇f​(θ;d),←𝜃𝜃𝜂∇𝑓𝜃𝑑\theta\leftarrow\theta-\eta\nabla f(\theta;d),

where d∈𝒟l𝑑subscript𝒟𝑙d\in\mathcal{D}_{l} represents a batch of data samples owned by client l𝑙l and η𝜂\eta is the learning rate.

After every E𝐸E local iterations, the PS conducts a global iteration by aggregating clients’ models following the rule

θt+1←1∑l∈𝒫tnl​∑l∈𝒫tnl​θt+1l,←subscript𝜃𝑡11subscript𝑙subscript𝒫𝑡subscript𝑛𝑙subscript𝑙subscript𝒫𝑡subscript𝑛𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡1𝑙\theta_{t+1}\leftarrow\frac{1}{\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}n_{l}}\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}n_{l}\theta_{t+1}^{l},

where 𝒫tsubscript𝒫𝑡\mathcal{P}_{t} represents the set of clients engaged in the global iteration t𝑡t. FedSGD is a special case of FedAvg by setting E=1𝐸1E=1 and d=𝒟l𝑑subscript𝒟𝑙d=\mathcal{D}_{l}. For both FedAvg and FedSGD, the PS can only communicate with a certain number of clients, which may be randomly selected due to the limitation of communication capacity.

To ease our discussion, we define the following notations. Let Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔T_{g} denote the total number of GIs to be executed, E𝐸E denote the number of LIs to be executed by each engaged client per GI and b𝑏b denote the number of clients engaged by the PS in each round of GI. Note that b𝑏b clients execute E𝐸E local iterations in parallel, and thus the total number of iterations T𝑇T to be executed is equal to the product of E𝐸E and Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔T_{g}, i.e., T=E​Tg𝑇𝐸subscript𝑇𝑔T=ET_{g}.

III-B Differential Privacy

Both FedAvg and FedSGD assume that the PS can be trusted and clients’ privacy cannot be cracked through gradient information. However, such assumptions are not always valid [6, 5, 7, 8]. Thereby, the DP technique is introduced to add noises to gradients generated by clients before their gradients are aggregated.

We briefly introduce the essential concepts in DP [20, 31] before we introduce how to incorporate DP into FedAvg.

Definition 1 ((ϵ,δitalic-ϵ𝛿\epsilon,\delta)-Differential Privacy).

A randomized function 𝔔𝔔\mathfrak{Q} gives ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differential privacy if for any data sets 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} and 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} differing on at most one entry, and all 𝒮⊆R​a​n​g​e​(𝔔)𝒮𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑔𝑒𝔔\mathcal{S}\subseteq Range(\mathfrak{Q}),

Pr⁡{𝔔​(𝒟1)∈𝒮}≤exp⁡(ϵ)×Pr⁡{𝔔​(𝒟2)∈𝒮}+δ.Pr𝔔subscript𝒟1𝒮italic-ϵPr𝔔subscript𝒟2𝒮𝛿\Pr\left\{\mathfrak{Q}(\mathcal{D}_{1})\in\mathcal{S}\right\}\leq\exp(\epsilon)\times\Pr\left\{\mathfrak{Q}(\mathcal{D}_{2})\in\mathcal{S}\right\}+\delta.

The traditional Laplace mechanism gives (ϵ,0)italic-ϵ0(\epsilon,0)-DP, while the Gaussian mechanism gives (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP. By tolerating some possibility of fails (represented by δ𝛿\delta), the Gaussian mechanism performs better on the utility under composition. We will introduce detailed Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms later. For generality, we use ℳℳ\mathcal{M} to denote the noise generator of DP mechanisms.

IV Client Based DP-FedAvg Algorithm

In this section, we introduce the client based DP-FedAvg algorithm and the implementation of two most frequently used DP mechanisms, i.e., Laplace and Gaussian.

IV-A Algorithm Framework

Before the algorithm details are presented, we define some useful notations as follows. The index set of FL GIs is defined as 𝒞E={1∗E,2∗E,…,Tg∗E}subscript𝒞𝐸1𝐸2𝐸…subscript𝑇𝑔𝐸\mathcal{C}_{E}=\left\{1*E,2*E,\dots,T_{g}*E\right\}. For any iteration in 𝒞Esubscript𝒞𝐸\mathcal{C}_{E}, the PS aggregates parameters returned by clients. For the sake of clarity, we use two indicators t𝑡t and k𝑘k throughout this paper where k=0,1,…,T𝑘01…𝑇k=0,1,\dots,T represents the index of any LI and t=0,1,2,…,Tg𝑡012…subscript𝑇𝑔t=0,1,2,\dots,T_{g} represents the index of any GI. The relation between k𝑘k and t𝑡t is t=⌊kE⌋𝑡𝑘𝐸t=\lfloor\frac{k}{E}\rfloor. It implies that the k𝑘k-th LI occurs just before the t𝑡t-th GI where t=⌊kE⌋𝑡𝑘𝐸t=\lfloor\frac{k}{E}\rfloor. In each round of GI, we formally define the set of clients who are engaged to exchange gradients with the PS as the engaged client pool (ECP) denoted as 𝒫tsubscript𝒫𝑡\mathcal{P}_{t} with cardinality b𝑏b. In our work, the clients in 𝒫tsubscript𝒫𝑡\mathcal{P}_{t} are selected from the complete client set 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} with a round robin manner.

The LIs are executed by a client only if the client is engaged in 𝒫tsubscript𝒫𝑡\mathcal{P}_{t}. The client receives the latest model from the PS (denoted by the parameter θt​Esubscript𝜃𝑡𝐸\theta_{tE} where t​E𝑡𝐸tE represents the total number of LIs conducted until the t𝑡t-th GI). Then, the client updates the model on the local dataset for E𝐸E rounds before the client returns the updated model with noises added with the rule θ^(t+1)​El=θ(t+1)​El+𝐰tlsuperscriptsubscript^𝜃𝑡1𝐸𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡1𝐸𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑙\hat{\theta}_{(t+1)E}^{l}=\theta_{(t+1)E}^{l}+\mathbf{w}_{t}^{l}. Here 𝐰tlsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑙\mathbf{w}_{t}^{l} represents the DP noises which will be further introduced later. The PS updates the model with the same rule of the FedAvg algorithm by aggregating models returned from engaged clients. The details of the client based DP-FedAvg algorithm are presented in Algorithm 1.

To facilitate our discussion, we present the overall iteration rules of Algorithm 1 here again as

where

is the average of noises from b𝑏b engaged clients. Here, for convenience, we use k𝑘k to denote the iteration index regardless of global or local iterations. For k+1∈𝒞E𝑘1subscript𝒞𝐸k+1\in\mathcal{C}_{E}, local parameters represented by θk+1lsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘1𝑙\theta_{k+1}^{l} will be aggregated with other engaged clients and DP noises.

Different from the original FedAvg algorithm, the DP noise (i.e., 𝐰tb=Nb​∑l∈𝒫tnln​𝐰tlsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑏𝑁𝑏subscript𝑙subscript𝒫𝑡subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑙\mathbf{w}_{t}^{b}=\frac{N}{b}\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\mathbf{w}_{t}^{l}) is the factor that can impede the convergence of DP-FedAvg. We name the term 𝐰tbsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑏\mathbf{w}_{t}^{b} as the “noise item”.

IV-B DP Mechanisms

The DP mechanism determines how to set 𝐰tlsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑙\mathbf{w}_{t}^{l} on each client before the updated model is returned to the server. In this work, we consider two most frequently used mechanisms (i.e., Laplace and Gaussian) in the convergence analysis. In fact, other DP mechanisms can be substituted into our framework as well by setting 𝐰tbsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑏\mathbf{w}_{t}^{b} with a different form.

According to the composition rule of DP [31], we cannot consider the DP privacy budget for each iteration separately. Suppose that the PS conducts Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔T_{g} rounds of GIs, then each client will participate Tlsubscript𝑇𝑙T_{l} rounds of GIs where Tl=b​TgNsubscript𝑇𝑙𝑏subscript𝑇𝑔𝑁T_{l}=\frac{bT_{g}}{N}. Here we assume that the PS selects b𝑏b clients for every GI in a round robin manner and N𝑁N is the total number of clients in the system. Let η~t=maxt​E≤k<(t+1)​E⁡(ηk)subscript~𝜂𝑡subscript𝑡𝐸𝑘𝑡1𝐸subscript𝜂𝑘\tilde{\eta}_{t}=\max_{tE\leq k<(t+1)E}(\eta_{k}) where ηksubscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{k} denote the learning rate of the k𝑘k-th iteration. The Laplace and the Gaussian mechanisms can be defined as below.

Theorem 2 (Gaussian Mechanism [29]).

To simplify our analysis, we define the asymptotic variance of the DP noise item as follows.

Definition 2.

The asymptotic variance of the noise item of a DP mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is defined as 𝕍ℳ=O​(η~t2​E2​Tgz)subscript𝕍ℳ𝑂superscriptsubscript~𝜂𝑡2superscript𝐸2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑔𝑧\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}=O(\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2}T_{g}^{z}), where z∈[0,2]𝑧02z\in[0,2] is a constant number determined by the DP mechanism.

In the definition of the asymptotic variance, all variables not related with the number of LIs or GIs are regarded as constant numbers and ignored. We define 𝕍ℳsubscript𝕍ℳ\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}} based on the fact that η~t2​E2superscriptsubscript~𝜂𝑡2superscript𝐸2\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2} affects the function sensitivity, while Tl=bN​Tgsubscript𝑇𝑙𝑏𝑁subscript𝑇𝑔T_{l}=\frac{b}{N}T_{g} represents the number of GIs each client needs to participate. Meanwhile, we let 0≤z≤20𝑧20\leq z\leq 2 because the privacy budget at most increases linearly with Tlsubscript𝑇𝑙T_{l} according to the composition rule.333According to the composition rule in the DP theory, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP will be at most Tl​ϵsubscript𝑇𝑙italic-ϵT_{l}\epsilon-DP if the database is queried for Tlsubscript𝑇𝑙T_{l} times.

This is a very generic definition that can depict most existing DP mechanisms devised for FL, such as [10, 11]. The asymptotic variances of the noise items of the Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms introduced as above can be obtained as

𝕍Laplace=O​(η~t2​E2​Tg2).subscript𝕍Laplace𝑂superscriptsubscript~𝜂𝑡2superscript𝐸2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑔2\mathbb{V}_{\textit{Laplace}}=O(\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2}T_{g}^{2}). (2)
𝕍Gaussian=O​(η~t2​E2​Tg).subscript𝕍Gaussian𝑂superscriptsubscript~𝜂𝑡2superscript𝐸2subscript𝑇𝑔\mathbb{V}_{\textit{Gaussian}}=O(\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2}T_{g}). (3)

Obviously, how to set E𝐸E and Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔T_{g} will affect the variance of the noise item, and hence it will affect the convergence of DP-FedAvg. Meanwhile, we note that the asymptotic variance of the Gaussian mechanism is lower than that of the Laplace mechanism, and therefore the Gaussian mechanism can yield a better convergence rate. We conduct the convergence analysis of DP-FedAvg in the next section.

V Convergence Analysis of Client Based DP-FedAvg

In this section, we give the theoretic analysis of the convergence of FedAvg when DP mechanisms are applied on the client side.

V-A Definitions and Assumptions

In FL, it is well-known that the distribution of data samples is non-IID, that is, the training data samples of different clients may be drawn from distinct distributions. By leveraging the measure of the degree of non-IID in [18], we define the degree of non-IID as below.

Definition 3.

The degree of non-IID is quantified by

Γ=f∗−∑l∈𝒩nln​fl∗,Γsuperscript𝑓subscript𝑙𝒩subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑙\Gamma=f^{*}-\sum_{l\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}f_{l}^{*},

where f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} represents the loss function with global optimal parameters and fl∗superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑙f_{l}^{*} represents the loss function with local optimal parameters.

To ease our discussion, we define θ¯k=∑l∈𝒩nln​θklsubscript¯𝜃𝑘subscript𝑙𝒩subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑙\bar{\theta}_{k}=\sum_{l\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\theta_{k}^{l} and ν¯k=∑l∈𝒩nln​νklsubscript¯𝜈𝑘subscript𝑙𝒩subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑙\bar{\nu}_{k}=\sum_{l\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nu_{k}^{l} to denote the global parameters by averaging over all clients. Similarly, we also define ν¯kb=Nb​∑l∈𝒫tnln​νklsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜈𝑘𝑏𝑁𝑏subscript𝑙subscript𝒫𝑡subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑙\bar{\nu}_{k}^{b}=\frac{N}{b}\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nu_{k}^{l} to denote the sampled global parameters. We use ∇f​(θk)=∑l∈𝒩nln​∇fl​(θkl)∇𝑓subscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝑙𝒩subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛∇subscript𝑓𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑙\nabla f(\theta_{k})=\sum_{l\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nabla f_{l}(\theta_{k}^{l}) to denote the global gradient and ∇fb​(θk)=Nb​∑l∈𝒫tnln​∇fl​(θkl)∇subscript𝑓𝑏subscript𝜃𝑘𝑁𝑏subscript𝑙subscript𝒫𝑡subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛∇subscript𝑓𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑙\nabla f_{b}(\theta_{k})=\frac{N}{b}\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nabla f_{l}(\theta_{k}^{l}) to denote the sampled global gradient.

Definition 4.

Define Yk=𝔼​{‖θ¯k−θ∗‖22}subscript𝑌𝑘𝔼superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript¯𝜃𝑘superscript𝜃22Y_{k}=\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\|\bar{\theta}_{k}-\theta^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right\} as the expected distance between the current, global parameters and the optimal parameters after k𝑘k iterations.

Similar to the assumptions made in many previous papers [32, 33, 34, 18], we also make the same following assumptions to simplify our analysis.

Assumption 1.

The loss function f𝑓f is λ𝜆\lambda-smooth. Formally, there exists a constant λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0, and

f​(θ)≤f​(θ′)+⟨∇f​(θ′),θ−θ′⟩+λ2​‖θ−θ′‖22.𝑓𝜃𝑓superscript𝜃′∇𝑓superscript𝜃′𝜃superscript𝜃′𝜆2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜃superscript𝜃′22f(\theta)\leq f(\theta^{\prime})+\left<\nabla f(\theta^{\prime}),\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right>+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left\|\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right\|_{2}^{2}.
Assumption 2.

The loss function f𝑓f is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex. Formally, there exists a constant μ>0𝜇0\mu>0, and

f​(θ)≥f​(θ′)+⟨∇f​(θ′),θ−θ′⟩+μ2​‖θ−θ′‖22.𝑓𝜃𝑓superscript𝜃′∇𝑓superscript𝜃′𝜃superscript𝜃′𝜇2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜃superscript𝜃′22f(\theta)\geq f(\theta^{\prime})+\left<\nabla f(\theta^{\prime}),\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right>+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right\|_{2}^{2}.
Assumption 3.

The expectation of gradients is bounded in terms of

𝔼​{‖∇fl​(θkl)‖22}≤G2,∀l∈𝒩,0≤k<T.formulae-sequence𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑙22superscript𝐺2formulae-sequencefor-all𝑙𝒩0𝑘𝑇\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\|\nabla f_{l}(\theta_{k}^{l})\right\|_{2}^{2}\right\}\leq G^{2},\,\forall l\in\mathcal{N},0\leq k<T.

V-B Convergence Rate of DP-FedAvg

To derive the upper bound of the convergence rate of Client based DP-FedAvg, we need to utilize the following lemmas.

Lemma 1 (Unbiased sample).

The round robin sampling of clients is unbiased, and thus we have

𝔼​{ν¯kb}=ν¯k.𝔼superscriptsubscript¯𝜈𝑘𝑏subscript¯𝜈𝑘\mathbb{E}\left\{\bar{\nu}_{k}^{b}\right\}=\bar{\nu}_{k}.
Lemma 2 (Bounding the divergence of the parameters of sampled clients in 𝒫tsubscript𝒫𝑡\mathcal{P}_{t}).

Let Assumption 3 hold, the gap between ν¯k+1bsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜈𝑘1𝑏\bar{\nu}_{k+1}^{b} and ν¯k+1subscript¯𝜈𝑘1\bar{\nu}_{k+1} is bounded as

𝔼​{‖ν¯k+1b−ν¯k+1‖22}≤4​E2​ηk2​G2​N−bN−1​1b.𝔼superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜈𝑘1𝑏subscript¯𝜈𝑘1224superscript𝐸2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑘2superscript𝐺2𝑁𝑏𝑁11𝑏\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\|\bar{\nu}_{k+1}^{b}-\bar{\nu}_{k+1}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right\}\leq 4E^{2}\eta_{k}^{2}G^{2}\frac{N-b}{N-1}\frac{1}{b}.
Lemma 3 (Bounding the divergence of local parameters).

Let Assumption 3 hold, the expectation of the average distance between θ¯ksubscript¯𝜃𝑘\bar{\theta}_{k} and θklsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑙\theta_{k}^{l}’s is

𝔼​{∑l∈𝒩nln‖θ¯k−θkl∥22}≤4​ηk2​(E−1)2​G2.𝔼conditional-setsubscript𝑙𝒩subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛subscript¯𝜃𝑘evaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑙224superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑘2superscript𝐸12superscript𝐺2\mathbb{E}\left\{\sum_{l\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\left\|\bar{\theta}_{k}-\theta_{k}^{l}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right\}\leq 4\eta_{k}^{2}(E-1)^{2}G^{2}.
Lemma 4 (Upper bound in one step of FedAvg).

Let Assumption 1, 2 and 3 hold, in one step of DP-FedAvg, we have

‖ν¯k+1−θ∗‖22=(1−μ​ηk)​‖θ¯k−θ∗‖22+2​∑l∈𝒩nln​‖θ¯k−θkl‖22+6​λ​ηk2​Γ.superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript¯𝜈𝑘1superscript𝜃221𝜇subscript𝜂𝑘superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript¯𝜃𝑘superscript𝜃222subscript𝑙𝒩subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript¯𝜃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑙226𝜆superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑘2Γ\begin{split}\left\|\bar{\nu}_{k+1}-\theta^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}&=(1-\mu\eta_{k})\left\|\bar{\theta}_{k}-\theta^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2}\\ &\quad+2\sum_{l\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\left\|\bar{\theta}_{k}-\theta_{k}^{l}\right\|_{2}^{2}+6\lambda\eta_{k}^{2}\Gamma.\end{split}

The detailed proof of Lemma 1 is presented in Appendix. The proof of Lemma 2 and 3 can be found in [18]. Lemma 4 can be proved by modifying the proof of in [18] a little bit. The only difference is that each client executes local iterations with a full batch of samples owned by the client in our case.

Theorem 3.

Let Assumptions 1, 2 and 3 hold, and ηk=2μ​1k+γsubscript𝜂𝑘2𝜇1𝑘𝛾\eta_{k}=\frac{2}{\mu}\frac{1}{k+\gamma} where γ=max⁡(8​λμ,E)𝛾8𝜆𝜇𝐸\gamma=\max(8\frac{\lambda}{\mu},E). The convergence rate of the DP-FedAvg algorithm is bounded by

Yk≤1k+γ​(4μ2​ω0+γ​Y0)+4μ2​t(k+γ−1)2​ω1,ω0=6​λ​Γ+8​(E−1)2​G2+4​E2​G2​N−bN−1​1b,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑌𝑘1𝑘𝛾4superscript𝜇2subscript𝜔0𝛾subscript𝑌04superscript𝜇2𝑡superscript𝑘𝛾12subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔06𝜆Γ8superscript𝐸12superscript𝐺24superscript𝐸2superscript𝐺2𝑁𝑏𝑁11𝑏\begin{split}&Y_{k}\leq\frac{1}{k+\gamma}\left(\frac{4}{\mu^{2}}\omega_{0}+\gamma Y_{0}\right)+\frac{4}{\mu^{2}}\frac{t}{(k+\gamma-1)^{2}}\omega_{1},\\ &\omega_{0}=6\lambda\Gamma+8(E-1)^{2}G^{2}+4E^{2}G^{2}\frac{N-b}{N-1}\frac{1}{b},\\ \end{split}

where ω1=Cℳ​E2​Tgzsubscript𝜔1subscript𝐶ℳsuperscript𝐸2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑔𝑧\omega_{1}=C_{\mathcal{M}}E^{2}T_{g}^{z} and Cℳsubscript𝐶ℳC_{\mathcal{M}} represents a constant number related with the DP mechanism. For example, Cℳ=8​p​b​ξ12N2​ϵ2subscript𝐶ℳ8𝑝𝑏superscriptsubscript𝜉12superscript𝑁2superscriptitalic-ϵ2C_{\mathcal{M}}=8pb\frac{\xi_{1}^{2}}{N^{2}\epsilon^{2}} for Laplace mechanism and Cℳ=8​p​c22​log⁡(1/δ)​ξ22N​ϵ2subscript𝐶ℳ8𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑐221𝛿superscriptsubscript𝜉22𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ2C_{\mathcal{M}}=8pc_{2}^{2}\log(1/\delta)\frac{\xi_{2}^{2}}{N\epsilon^{2}} for Gaussian mechanism. Here z𝑧z is a constant number defined in Definition 2, and its value is dependent on the DP mechanism.

Here, we derive the convergence rate of DP-FedAvg with a general DP mechanism. t𝑡t is the index of the global iteration, and thus t=⌊kE⌋𝑡𝑘𝐸t=\lfloor\frac{k}{E}\rfloor. As we can see from the convergence rate, ω0subscript𝜔0\omega_{0} governs the convergence of DP-FedAvg without the noise item; while ω1subscript𝜔1\omega_{1} is the influence of the noise item on the convergence rate. The proof of Theorem 3 leverages Lemmas 1, 2, 3 and 4, which can be found in the Appendix with details.

V-C Asymptotic Analysis

To focus on the influence of iteration times, we conduct asymptotic analysis of the convergence rate by regarding all variables not related to the LI or GI as constant numbers.

V-C1 Convergence Conditions

The convergence rate derived in Theorem 3 can be simplified as

YTsubscript𝑌𝑇\displaystyle Y_{T} =\displaystyle= O​(E2T)+O​(ω1E​T),𝑂superscript𝐸2𝑇𝑂subscript𝜔1𝐸𝑇\displaystyle O\left(\frac{E^{2}}{T}\right)+O\left(\frac{\omega_{1}}{ET}\right), (4)
=\displaystyle= O​(E2T)+O​(E1−z​Tz−1).𝑂superscript𝐸2𝑇𝑂superscript𝐸1𝑧superscript𝑇𝑧1\displaystyle O\left(\frac{E^{2}}{T}\right)+O\left(E^{1-z}T^{z-1}\right).

Here, we utilize the fact that ω1=O​(E2​Tgz)subscript𝜔1𝑂superscript𝐸2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑔𝑧\omega_{1}=O(E^{2}T_{g}^{z}) and E​Tg=T𝐸subscript𝑇𝑔𝑇ET_{g}=T is the total number of iterations. Through Eq. (4), we prove the convergence conditions of DP-FedAvg as follows.

Theorem 4.

YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} of the client based DP-FedAvg with the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} will converge to 00 as T𝑇T approaches infinity, if z<1𝑧1z<1 in 𝕍ℳsubscript𝕍ℳ\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}. The number of LIs should be set as E=O​(Tzz+1)𝐸𝑂superscript𝑇𝑧𝑧1E=O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}) to achieve the fastest convergence rate O​(Tz−1z+1)𝑂superscript𝑇𝑧1𝑧1O(T^{\frac{z-1}{z+1}}).

Proof.

We first prove the convergence conditions. From the first term in Eq. 4, we have E<O​(T)𝐸𝑂𝑇E<O(\sqrt{T}), otherwise the first term will diverge. Thus, for the second term we have O​(E1−z​Tz−1)<O​(T1−z2+z−1)𝑂superscript𝐸1𝑧superscript𝑇𝑧1𝑂superscript𝑇1𝑧2𝑧1O(E^{1-z}T^{z-1})<O(T^{\frac{1-z}{2}+z-1}). It converges only if 1−z2+z−1<01𝑧2𝑧10\frac{1-z}{2}+z-1<0 which implies that z<1𝑧1z<1.

Then, we prove the optimal value of E𝐸E is O​(Tzz+1)𝑂superscript𝑇𝑧𝑧1O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}). Since YT=O​(E2T)+O​(E1−z​Tz−1)subscript𝑌𝑇𝑂superscript𝐸2𝑇𝑂superscript𝐸1𝑧superscript𝑇𝑧1Y_{T}=O(\frac{E^{2}}{T})+O(E^{1-z}T^{z-1}), it is a convex function with respect to E𝐸E. By letting the differentiation of YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} with respect to E𝐸E equal to 00, we have O​(ET)+O​(E−z​Tz−1)=0𝑂𝐸𝑇𝑂superscript𝐸𝑧superscript𝑇𝑧10O(\frac{E}{T})+O(E^{-z}T^{z-1})=0. It turns out that we should set E=O​(Tzz+1)𝐸𝑂superscript𝑇𝑧𝑧1E=O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}). ∎

Theorem 5.

YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} of the client based DP-FedAvg with the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} cannot converge to 00 as T𝑇T approaches infinity, if z≥1𝑧1z\geq 1 in 𝕍ℳsubscript𝕍ℳ\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}. The number of LIs should be set as E=O​(Tzz+1)𝐸𝑂superscript𝑇𝑧𝑧1E=O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}) to minimize the influence of the DP noise item, which gives rise to the lowest divergence rate O​(Tz−1z+1)𝑂superscript𝑇𝑧1𝑧1O(T^{\frac{z-1}{z+1}}).

Proof.

From the proof of Theorem 4, we can see that YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} cannot converge if z≥1𝑧1z\geq 1.

Similar to the proof of Theorem 4, we should set E=O​(Tzz+1)𝐸𝑂superscript𝑇𝑧𝑧1E=O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}) to achieve YT=O​(Tz−1z+1)subscript𝑌𝑇𝑂superscript𝑇𝑧1𝑧1Y_{T}=O(T^{\frac{z-1}{z+1}}). However, due to z≥1𝑧1z\geq 1, YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} will diverge with the minimum rate O​(Tz−1z+1)𝑂superscript𝑇𝑧1𝑧1O(T^{\frac{z-1}{z+1}}) as T𝑇T approaches infinity. ∎

Corollary 5.1.

If z>1𝑧1z>1 in 𝕍ℳsubscript𝕍ℳ\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}, there exists a T∗<∞superscript𝑇T^{*}<\infty that can minimize YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T}.

The proof is straightforward given that YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} is a convex function with respect to T𝑇T and YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} will diverge if z>1𝑧1z>1. Unfortunately, it is extremely difficult to precisely derive T∗superscript𝑇T^{*} due to the difficulty to exactly estimate the value of each parameter such as μ𝜇\mu, ΓΓ\Gamma and G𝐺G in YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T}.

V-C2 Case Study

For the Laplace and the Gaussian mechanisms, they are the special cases of our general analysis. For the Laplace mechanism, we have z=2𝑧2z=2, which implies that the Laplace mechanism can never converge. The divergence rate can be minimized by setting E𝐸E as an increasing function of T𝑇T. According to the Theorem 5, we should set E=O​(T23)𝐸𝑂superscript𝑇23E=O(T^{\frac{2}{3}}) and YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} will diverge with the lowest rate O​(T13)𝑂superscript𝑇13O(T^{\frac{1}{3}}) as T𝑇T approaches infinity.

Remark: We can see the significance of our study from This case study. If we set E=O​(1)𝐸𝑂1E=O(1) for the Laplace mechanism, YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} will diverge with the rate O​(T)𝑂𝑇O(T), which is much higher than the optimal rate O​(T13)𝑂superscript𝑇13O(T^{\frac{1}{3}}). Thus, setting E𝐸E properly with our method can markedly improve the practicability of DP in FL.

The DP based FedAvg with the Gaussian mechanism is a very special case. According to the Theorem 5, YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} cannot converge to 00. However, if we set E=O​(1)𝐸𝑂1E=O(1), YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} will converge to O​(1)𝑂1O(1) as T𝑇T approaches infinity.

VI Experiment

In this section, we carry out extensive experiments with two real-world datasets to validate our theoretical analysis.

VI-A Dataset Description and Preprocessing

VI-A1 Lending Club Dataset

The Lending Club dataset [10] contains about 890,000890000890,000 loan data records. Each record in the dataset includes some features of borrowers (e.g., zip code, address, request amount of money, and interest rate).

The dataset is used to predict customers’ interest rates. We first clean the data by discarding meaningless features (e.g., ID, address, and job title). Then we convert some valuable text features to numbers, such as job year and grade. We discard those features missed by more than 70%percent7070\% of data records. After the above preprocessing operations, there remain 666666 features, though some features are redundant and some are almost always 00. We use Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to further reduce 666666 features into 101010 effective features. In the experiments, we use randomly sampled 500,000500000500,000 data records as the whole dataset. And then we randomly sample 80%percent8080\% data as the training dataset and the rest as the test dataset. To setup the non-IID distribution, all records in the training dataset are sorted by the interest rate in ascending order before they are evenly grouped into N=5,000𝑁5000N=5,000 groups. Each client will be assigned a single sample group.

VI-A2 FEMNIST Dataset

FEMNIST is an open source dataset presented in [35] as a benchmark for FL study. FEMNIST contains 803,267803267803,267 hand-written image samples written by 3,50035003,500 users. There are 626262 labels (i.e., 101010 digits, 262626 lowercase, 262626 uppercase) in the dataset. We use 90%percent9090\% samples to train the model and the rest as the test set. Because FEMNIST is naturally unbalanced and non-IID, we simulate 3,50035003,500 clients and assign each client with a user’s samples.

VI-B Models and Experimental Settings

We construct a Linear Regression (LR) model with 111111 parameters for the Lending Club dataset to predict the interest rate of each borrower. Mean Square Error (MSE) is used to define the loss function and evaluate the model prediction performance.

For the FEMNIST dataset, we construct a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model to classify images. The CNN model consists of two convolutional layers followed by one fully connected layer. The first convolution layer uses 7×7777\times 7 kernels with padding 333. The second layer uses 3×3333\times 3 kernels with padding 111. The first layers has 323232 channels while the second has 646464 channels. Both convolutional layers are followed by a ReLU and 2×2222\times 2 max pool. The fully connected layer has 626262 units and takes the flatted output of the second convolutional layer as the input. The CNN model contains 214,590214590214,590 parameters. CrossEntropy is used to define the loss function.

In the experiments, we use the MSE loss function and the model accuracy on the test datasets to evaluate the LR model and CNN model, respectively. We can evaluate the model performance over the test set after each round of global iteration. If E>1𝐸1E>1, the model is only evaluated when k∈𝒞E𝑘subscript𝒞𝐸k\in\mathcal{C}_{E}.

For each case, we implement a benchmark model, which is a special case with ϵ=∞italic-ϵ\epsilon=\infty, i.e., there is no DP noise. To get rid of the influence of the randomness due to random noises and random client selection in ECPs, we plot the average results by executing each experiment case for 202020 times. By default, we set b=500𝑏500b=500 for the LR model and b=350𝑏350b=350 for the CNN model.

We impose the Laplace mechanism on the LR model and the Gaussian mechanism on the CNN model. Throughout the following experiments, we set a fixed δ=0.0001𝛿0.0001\delta=0.0001 for the Gaussian mechanism.

In practice, it is very difficult to exactly compute the sensitivity, i.e., ξ𝜉\xi, of the gradient functions, and thus we use the norm clipping technique with a clipping threshold ζ𝜁\zeta to restrict the range of client’s gradients. If a client’s some gradient exceeds ζ𝜁\zeta, it will be clipped to ζ𝜁\zeta. Formally, the gradient is clipped by

∇fl​(θk)=∇fl​(θk)/max⁡(1,‖∇fl​(θk)‖1ζ),∇subscript𝑓𝑙subscript𝜃𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝑙subscript𝜃𝑘1subscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑙subscript𝜃𝑘1𝜁\nabla{f}_{l}(\theta_{k})=\nabla f_{l}(\theta_{k})/\max\left(1,\frac{\left\|\nabla f_{l}(\theta_{k})\right\|_{1}}{\zeta}\right),

where we set ζ=150𝜁150\zeta=150 for LR model and ζ=3𝜁3\zeta=3 for CNN model. This technique is firstly introduced by [29] and widely used in the implementation of DP in practical machine learning systems [25, 13].

VI-C Results and Discussions

In this part, we present the results of our experiments.

VI-C1 Impact of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon

To inspect the influence of the privacy budge on the model training process, we conduct experiments by enumerating different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon’s. For the LR model, we set T=100,E=1formulae-sequence𝑇100𝐸1T=100,E=1 and ϵ=1.0,3.0,5.0italic-ϵ1.03.05.0\epsilon=1.0,3.0,5.0 or ∞\infty; while for the CNN model, we set T=250,E=5formulae-sequence𝑇250𝐸5T=250,E=5 and ϵ=10.0,20.0,30.0italic-ϵ10.020.030.0\epsilon=10.0,20.0,30.0 or ∞\infty. Note that we set relatively large ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon’s for the CNN model due to the large number of parameters in CNN. Similar ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon’s were also used in other works such as [11, 10].

The loss function of the LR model is obtained on the test set of the Lending Club dataset. In Fig. 1, we can observe that there exists a gap between the loss function curves with DP noises and the loss function curve with ϵ=∞italic-ϵ\epsilon=\infty. In particular, the loss function diverges rapidly when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is very small. It shows the challenge to make DP based FL practical, especially when the privacy budget is small.

The accuracy of the CNN model evaluated on the FEMNIST test set is plotted in Fig. 2 against the iteration times. In Fig. 2, we can draw a similar conclusion that the model accuracy can be impaired by the DP noises significantly such that implementing DP in FL is challenge when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is small.

VI-C2 Impact of T𝑇T

We conduct experiments to verify Theorem 5, which states that: 1) YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} approaches infinity as T𝑇T increases and there exists some T∗<∞superscript𝑇T^{*}<\infty such that YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} is optimized if the Laplace mechanism is adopted; 2) YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} converges to O​(1)𝑂1O(1) as T𝑇T approaches infinity if the Gaussian mechanism is adopted.

In Fig. 3, we evaluate the LR model using the Lending Club dataset and the Laplace mechanism by varying T𝑇T from 00 to 100100100 with a step size 101010 and set E=1𝐸1E=1. We plot the loss function YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} against T𝑇T. Note that YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} is different from Yksubscript𝑌𝑘Y_{k} where YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} is the final loss after T𝑇T iterations and Yksubscript𝑌𝑘Y_{k} is the loss after k𝑘k iterations. We also show the accurate value of T∗superscript𝑇T^{*} and the corresponding loss in Table II. As we can see that the loss function diverges finally as T𝑇T increases. For each experiment case, there exists some T∗superscript𝑇T^{*} such that the minimum value of the loss function is achieved.

For the CNN model, we use the FEMNIST dataset for evaluation by varying T𝑇T from 00 to 500500500 with a step size of 505050 and E=5𝐸5E=5. As shown in Fig. 4, the model accuracy gets stable at some value as T𝑇T approaches infinity per the Gaussian mechanism is adopted. This result implies that YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} approaches O​(1)𝑂1O(1) instead of diverging to infinity as T𝑇T approaches infinity.

VI-C3 Impact of E𝐸E

We conduct experiments to show the importance to tune E𝐸E, i.e., the number of local iterations, in DP-FedAvg.

We enumerate different E𝐸E’s to see how E𝐸E can affect the model training process. In Fig. 5, we evaluate the LR model using the Lending Club dataset and the Laplace mechanism, by enumerating E=1,2,3,4,6,12𝐸1234612E=1,2,3,4,6,12 and fixing T=120𝑇120T=120 with different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon’s. Similarly, in Fig. 6, we evaluate the CNN model by fixing T=240𝑇240T=240 and enumerating E=1,2,3,4,6,8,12,24𝐸1234681224E=1,2,3,4,6,8,12,24 with different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon’s. To accurately show the optimal E𝐸E, we list the results in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 in Table III and Table IV.

Through observing Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, we can draw the following observations.

  • •

    In both Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, for all cases with different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon’s, if E𝐸E has not been set properly, the performance of the trained model can be very poor. For example, the loss function of the LR model is very high if E=1𝐸1E=1 when ϵ=1.0italic-ϵ1.0\epsilon=1.0. This experiment manifests the importance to tune E𝐸E in DP based FL.

  • •

    E𝐸E should be neither too large or too small. Intuitively, if E𝐸E is too large, it means Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔T_{g} will be too small and the model training process is not iterated sufficiently. Inversely, if E𝐸E is too small, it means Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔T_{g} is too large, and hence the model training process can be impaired by the large DP noises. Recall that 𝕍ℳ=O​(η~t2​E2​Tgz)subscript𝕍ℳ𝑂superscriptsubscript~𝜂𝑡2superscript𝐸2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑔𝑧\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}=O(\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2}T_{g}^{z}).

  • •

    Through comparing cases with different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon’s in both figures, we can find the rule of thumb that E𝐸E should be set a larger value if ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is smaller.

To verify Theorem 4, we conduct the experiment by using the Lending Club dataset and the Laplace mechanism. In this experiment, we set E𝐸E as a function of T𝑇T. Specifically, we enumerate E=1,T13,T12,T23​ or ​T𝐸1superscript𝑇13superscript𝑇12superscript𝑇23 or 𝑇E=1,T^{\frac{1}{3}},T^{\frac{1}{2}},T^{\frac{2}{3}}\textit{ or }T by varying T𝑇T from 111 to 120120120 with a step size of 101010. Note in this experiment, we set b=5000𝑏5000b=5000 to enable very small Tgsubscript𝑇𝑔T_{g} (i.e., Tg=1subscript𝑇𝑔1T_{g}=1). If E𝐸E (as a function of T𝑇T) is not an integer, it will be rounded to the nearest integer. According to Theorem 4, it is optimal to set E∗=T2/3superscript𝐸superscript𝑇23E^{*}=T^{2/3}. The result is presented in Fig. 7, which indeed confirms the correctness of our theoretical analysis. The curve with E=T23𝐸superscript𝑇23E=T^{\frac{2}{3}} is the best one achieving the lowest loss function. Although, YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T} will diverge with the increase of T𝑇T, its divergence rate is very low if E=T23𝐸superscript𝑇23E=T^{\frac{2}{3}}. Another important implication is that the setting of T𝑇T is not very sensitive if E𝐸E is chosen properly.

VII Conclusion

We investigate the practicability of DP mechanisms in FL. A general DP based FedAvg algorithm is presented first. Then, both the Laplace mechanism and the Gaussian mechanism are introduced into the general DP based FedAvg algorithm. Through tuning the number of local/global iterations, we show from both theoretical analysis and experimental study that it is very important to set the number of iteration times properly such that the influence of the DP noises can be minimized. Specifically, via defining the asymptotic variance of the DP noises, we derive the conditions for DP-FedAvg to converge, and the optimal choice of the number of local iterations. The Lending Club and FEMNIST datasets are utilized to conduct extensive experiments. The experiment results not only verify our theoretical analysis, but also demonstrates that the choice of the number of local iterations can heavily affect the model training performance.

Proof.

Appendix E Proof of Lemma 1

Proof.

Taking expectation, we obtain

𝔼​{ν¯kb}=Nb​𝔼​{∑l∈𝒫tnln​νkl}=Nb​∑𝒫∈ϕb​(𝒩)1c​(∑l∈𝒫nln​νkl),𝔼superscriptsubscript¯𝜈𝑘𝑏𝑁𝑏𝔼subscript𝑙subscript𝒫𝑡subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑙𝑁𝑏subscript𝒫subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏𝒩1𝑐subscript𝑙𝒫subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑙\begin{split}\mathbb{E}\left\{\bar{\nu}_{k}^{b}\right\}&=\frac{N}{b}\mathbb{E}\left\{\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nu_{k}^{l}\right\}\\ &=\frac{N}{b}\sum_{\mathcal{P}\in\phi_{b}(\mathcal{N})}\frac{1}{c}\left(\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nu_{k}^{l}\right),\end{split} (5)

where ϕb​(𝒩)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏𝒩\phi_{b}(\mathcal{N}) represents the set of all subset of 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} whose size is b𝑏b, and c=|ϕb​(𝒩)|𝑐subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏𝒩c=|\phi_{b}(\mathcal{N})|. For instance, if 𝒩={1,2,3}𝒩123\mathcal{N}=\left\{1,2,3\right\}, ϕ2​(𝒩)={{1,2},{1,3},{2,3}},c=3.formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϕ2𝒩121323𝑐3\phi_{2}(\mathcal{N})=\left\{\left\{1,2\right\},\left\{1,3\right\},\left\{2,3\right\}\right\},c=3. Because we sample clients with equal probability and without replacement, each client appears identically and at most once in every 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}. Therefore, since there are totally c​b𝑐𝑏cb clients sampled, each client is sampled c​bN𝑐𝑏𝑁\frac{cb}{N} times. We change the order of summation and obtain

∑𝒫∈ϕb​(𝒩)∑l∈𝒫nln​νkl=∑l∈𝒩c​bN​nln​νkl.subscript𝒫subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏𝒩subscript𝑙𝒫subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑙subscript𝑙𝒩𝑐𝑏𝑁subscript𝑛𝑙𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜈𝑘𝑙\sum_{\mathcal{P}\in\phi_{b}(\mathcal{N})}\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nu_{k}^{l}=\sum_{l\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{cb}{N}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nu_{k}^{l}.

Plugging this into (5) and recalling the definition of ν¯ksubscript¯𝜈𝑘\bar{\nu}_{k}, we finish the proof. ∎
